_prev_prog_3.Description: This is a batch process, in which all reactions are carried out in a stirred tank, batch reactor.  The regulated substance associated with this process is dimethylamine (DMA).  The largest amount is stored in a pressure vessel rated at 250 pounds per square inch gauge pressure (psi), far below the tank pressure rating.  The tank is protected from an overpressure that might rupture it by the rupture discs and safety relief valves installed on the tank.  As DMA is loaded into the storage tank, a closed loop piping system is employed to recycle the DMA vapors back to the delivery truck while the DMA liquid is being pumped into the storage tank.  The DMA storage tank is permanently grounded, and the delivery trailer is temporarily grounded during the unloading process to prevent static electricity buildup and sparking that could potentially cause combustion of a hydrocarbon.  The delivery truck driver and plant operator are present during the unloading process to make corrections required to ensure the safe unloading of DMA.  The truck driver and plant operator assigned have both been trained in the safe handling of DMA. The DMA storage tank is located in an approximately 60 ft. by 34 ft. by 45 in. high diked area.  A water deluge system is in place around the tank and can be remotely operated to suppress any excess emissions that might result from any tank, piping, or equipment leak within the containment dike.  The pumps used to transfer the DMA from the storage tank to the batch are also located in the containment area.  An excess flow valve is installed in the line from the tank to the delivery pump that will activate and shutdown the flow of DMA in case of a line rupture or any excessive DMA flow from the storage tank.  A check valve is also installed in the reactor delivery line to prevent contamination of the DMA in the storage tank.  The reactor is a water jacketed, stirred tank, pressure vessel.  The water jacket is used to control the reactor temperature, which helps control the reaction and reactor pressure.  The reactor mixer shaft contains a double mechanical seal to prevent leakage of gases and liquids from the reactor.  The reactor is also protected from overpressurization by rupture discs and safety relief valves.  The reactor is vented to the plant scrubber system to control emissions that might occur during the reactor filling cycle.  A safety shower and emergency eye wash are located in the immediate reactor area and in the truck delivery area.  The operators and supervisors are trained to prevent any unsafe operation of the complete process.  The personnel and supervisors are also trained to implement emergency response procedures in case of an emergency.  Routine maintenance procedures are implemented and documented.  A mechanical inspection of the process and safety equipment was conducted initially and is conducted annually to ensure mechanical integrity and correct any deficiencies that might be discovered.

The hydrogenation process is a batch process where basic chemical are reacted in a pressurized, stirred tank reactor to produce a product.  The regulated substances for this process are ammonia, hydrogen, acrylonitrile, and formaldehyde.  The largest quantity of each regulated substance onsite is in its respective storage tank.  The batch reactor is protected from a potential catastrophic rupture caused by overpressurization using safety relief devices.  The reactor is vented to the plant scrubber system when it is being loaded or depressurized to prevent excess emissions to the atmosphere.  Nitrogen is used to purge the reactor of oxygen to prevent a flammable mixture that could potentially ignite.  A safety shower, eyewash, and protective equipment are located near the reactor.  The acrylonitrile storage tank is a 250 psig rated pressure vessel.  Nitrogen is used as a blanket in the tank to prevent oxygen from coming in contact with the acrylonitrile vapors.  Without oxygen, the acrylonitrile vapors can not be ignited.  The tank pressure is also controlled by the nitrogen to 125 psig, well below the pressure rating of the tank.  Safety relief devices vent to the atmosphere to protect the tank from catastrophic rutpure by an unlikely overpressurization.  The piping and tank were inspected prior to being placed in service and are inspected on an annual basis.  A remotely controlled water deluge system is constructed around the storage tank.  The storage tank is also located in a diked area that is large enough to contain the contents of the tank and deluge water, should such a situation occur.  A closed loop vapor recycle system is used to fill the tank.  The ammonia storage tank is also a 250 psig rated pressure vessel with relief devices installed to prevent a catastrophic rupture of the tank.  An excess flow valve is installed between the tank and piping.  Should a pipe line rupture or ammonia is fed too fast to the reactor, the excess flow valve will shut automatically within one second to prevent a major release of ammonia to the atmosphere.  A closed loop vapor recycle system is also used for delivery of ammonia to the storage tank.  The hydrogen storage tank is a refrigerated vessel kept at -427 degrees F.  Hydrogen pressure at this temperature is 14.7 psig.  This tank also has safety relief devices to prevent catastrophic rupture of the tank.  The tank is also insulated to assist in the control of the hydrogen temperature.  Should the refrigeration system malfunction, the release of hydrogen from the safety relief device (along with the tank insulation) will keep the hydrogen in the tank cold enough so that only small quantities of hydrogen are released at one time.  All plant operators, supervisors, and truck drivers are trained to handle their respective chemicals in a safe manner and are prepared to handle emergency situations that might arise.  A formal maintenance reporting and action plan is in place to correct leaks or equipment malfunctions in a timely manner that might occur.

The Quat process is a batch process operation using a stirred tank, pressure reactor with a double mechanical sealed mixer shaft.  The reactor is protected from catastrophic rupture caused by overpressures by safety relief devices.  Nitrogen is used to purge the reactor of oxygen prior to filling.  The reactor pressure and temperature, like all of the other batch reactors onsite, are controlled during the reaction by a reactor cooling water jacket and by the controlled addition of the reactive chemicals.  The reactor is vented to its own quench system that is consist of a pressure vessel containing the relatively inert liquid mixture of amine bottoms and isopropyl alcohol that willbe charged to the reactor for the next batch reaction.  This quench vessel is closed to the atmosphere and any vented reactive chemicals from the reactor will react completely with the contents of the vessel.  The listed chemical for this process are methyl chloride and trimethylamine.  Methyl chloride is stored in a 250 psig pressure rated vessel that is equipped with pressure relief devices to prevent a catastrophic rupture of the tank.  The ambient pressure of methyl chloride does not exceed 75 psig, which is well below the pressure rating of the vessel.  The tank is located within a diked area and is surrounded by a remotely controlled deluge system.   A firewater monitor is also located outside the diked area to help cool down the tank and control methyl chloride emissions, if required.  The tank is loaded from a tank delivery truck using a closed loop vapor recycle system as described in the other processes to minimize emissions to the atmosphere.  The delivery truck contents are verified with the storage tank contents by plant operators to ensure that the delivered chemicals are loaded into the proper storage tank.  The truck delivery hoses and connections are checked by the truck driver and plant operator for potential leaks.  Prior to coupling, the truck brakes are set, and the wheels are chocked to prevent movement.  The truck is grounded to prevent static electricity buildup and discharge.  The plant operator and truck driver remain with the truck during the unloading procedures.  Trimethylamine is stored in a 30,000 gallon tank rated at 250 psig.  Transfer from the rail car is conducted using compressor and vapor return lines.  The tank is located in a diked area.  It is equipped with remote shut-off valves, high level interlocks, and high temperature/pressure interlocks with the pump.  The tank is equipped with flammable gas detectors/alarms and flow detector, which when activated, automatically shut down the system.  A video camera is installed to monitor the area.  The pressure rating of the railroad tank car is 350 psig, and the tank car is approved by the DOT for safe transportation of trimethylamine.  The pressure relief device on the car is set at 280 psig to prevent a catastrophic rupture of the tank.  An excess flow valve is installed on the railroad tank car to shut down the flow of trimethylamine should a major leak develop in the trimethylamine piping or should the feed rate to the storage tank be too high.  When the railcar is spotted, the wheels are set and chocked.  The car is grounded and a derail block is placed at the head of the tracks.  Like the delivery trucks, the hoses and connectors are inspected for leaks.  Protective gear is used by plant personnel during this procedure.  A safety shower and eyewash is located in this area.  Self contained breathing units are readily available.  Plant operators and chemical truck drivers are trained and experienced in the safe handling of their respective chemicals and area trained to handle potential emergency situations.  The storage vessels, reactors and piping are inspected and tested before being placed in service and are inspected for mechanical integrity on an annual basis thereafter.  Like the rest of the processes reported, the formal maintenance program is applicable to this process.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary for Corsicana Technologies, Inc., Corsicana Plant

1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The Corsicana Technologies, Inc., Corsicana Plant, has always had a strong commitment to its employees to provide a safe working environment. This policy is consistent with both the spirit and the intent of our commitment.  The safety of employees, company operations, and the public are management's most important complete compliance with all safety regulations and safety policies.

Every attempt will be made to reduce the possibility of accident occurrence by all levels of management.  Corsicana believes that safety, like quality and housekeeping, can be controlled by motivated supervision.  Therefore, preventable lost time accidents will have an impact on a supervisor's annual salary review, including any bonuses and incentive plans.  Unreported accidents will be considered falsification of company records and will result in immediate discharge.  Lost time accident free locations will be eligible for annual awards.

2.  The Station Source and the Regulated Substances Handled
Corsicana operates a specialty chemical plant and manufactures fatty amines and nitrile intermediates.  The principal products are emulsifiers, corrosion inhibitors, de-emulsifiers, and surfactants.

We have eight regulated substances present at our facility as raw materials for processes, which include dimethylamine (DMA), acrylonitrile, anhydrous ammonia, hydrogen, formaldehyde, methyl chloride (MeCl), epichlorohydrin, and trimethylamine (TMA).  Acrylonitrile, anhydrous ammonia, formaldehyde, epichlorohydrin, and methyl chloride are regulated as toxic chemicals and trimethylamine, hydrogen, and dimethylamine are regulated as flammable chemicals.

 
3.  The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
Our facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out

under 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 of the EPA.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with ASME B31.3.  A number of processes at our facility are subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration(OSHA) Processes Safety Management (PSM) standard under 29 CFR 1910.119.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our stationary source.

Process Safety Information
Corsicana maintains a detailed record of process safety information that describes the hazards of regulated substances, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.  Much of the information was compiled during the preparation of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).  Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs).

Process Hazard Analysis
Our facility conduct comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently. Corsicana primarily uses the checklist and HAZOP method analysis techniques to perform these evaluations. The studies were undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and will be revalidated at regular intervals.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

For the purposes of safety conducting activities within our covered processes, Corsicana maintains written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in each covered process consistent with the process safety.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in

the processes.

Corsicana develops and implements safety work practices to provide for the control of hazards during operations such as lockout/tagout/confined space entry; opening process equipment or piping; and control over entrance into stationary source by maintenance, contractor, laboratory, or other support personnel.  These safe work practices apply to employees and contractor employees.

Training
Corsicana has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Initial training of operators is provided, and refresher training is provided as required.  Both initial and refresher training is documented and records of training are maintained onsite for at least 3 years.

Mechanical Integrity
Corsicana has written procedures for maintaining on-going integrity of process equipment, which incorporates training for process maintenance activities, inspection and testing, corrective action for equipment deficiencies and the application of quality assurance measures.  Corsicana carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper installation and operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others: pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, control and pumps.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified and trained personnel.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.  The plant also incorporates quality assurance measures to ensure that equipment and parts are suitable for the process application for which they will be used.

Management of Change
Written procedures are in place at Corsicana to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  These procedures will be updated as needed.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose j

ob tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.

Pre-startup Reviews
Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modification in established processes will be conducted as a regular practice at Corsicana.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications, and safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits
Corsicana conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented.  These audits are carried out by at least one person knowledgeable in the process and are conducted at least every 3 years.  Audit findings are documented in a report.  Any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner and are also documented.  The facility will maintain the two most recent compliance audit reports.

Incident Investigation
Corsicana promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  An incident investigation will be initiated as promptly as possible, but not later than 48 hours after the incident, and will involve at least one person knowledgeable of the process involved.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  A report will be prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and will include any resolutions and corrective action.  All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation
Corsicana believes that PSM and accidental prevention are a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend

improvements.  In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.

Hot Work Permit
Corsicana will issue a hot work permit for hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process.   Permit shall document that the fire prevention and protection requirements have been implemented prior to beginning the hot work operations; it shall indicate the date(s) authorized for hot work; and identify the object on which hot work is to be performed.  The permit will be kept on file until completion of the hot work operations.

Contractors
Corsicana hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  Before any contractors are allowed to work at Corsicana, they undergo an orientation conducted by the PSM team.  During this orientation contractors are made aware of the known potential hazards related to the contractor's work, the hazards of regulated substances within Corsicana, the safe work procedures insisted on by Corsicana, and familiarized with the Hot Work Permit Policy and the Lock Out/Tag Out procedures used at Corsicana.  Contractors are informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur, and this information includes evacuation routes and assembly points.  Corsicana will document that the contractor has received and understands the training.

Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
The processes at Corsicana have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operations.  Section 7 of the RMP describes existing safety features applicable to prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances at the facility.  The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all RMP-regulated processes at C

orsicana.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accidental scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human error.

4.  Five-year Accident History
The facility has not experienced any reportable accidents in the past 5 years.

5.  Emergency Response Program
Corsicana has a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous material, which is in place to protect workers and public safety, and the environment.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  Employees receive training in emergency procedures.  To ensure proper functioning, emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within processes that would require a modified emergency response.  The emergency plan has been coordinated with and verified by the Navarro County the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).

At all times there must be at least one employee either on the facility premises or on-call (i.e. available to respond to an emergency by reaching the facility within a short period of time) with the responsibility for coordination of all emergency response measures.  This emergency coordinator will be thoroughly familiar with all aspects of the facility's emergency response plan, all operations and activities at the facility, the location and characteristics of material/waste handled, the location of all records within the facility, and the facility layout.  In addition, this person will have the authority to commit the resources needed to carry out the emergency response plan.

6.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Corsicana will continue to improve safety at the facility through training.  No other upcoming events are
planned to improve safety at this time.
